title: 110_hr2399
content: The Act may be cited as the "Alien Smuggling and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2007". Congress recognizes the seriousness of alien smuggling as a transnational crime that threatens border integrity, national sovereignty, and security. Enforcement efforts by agencies like the Department of Homeland Security and Department of Justice are crucial in combating this threat. The law enforcement community requires effective statutory tools to address this security issue. Alien smuggling statutes are crucial for successful prosecution by the Justice Department. Smuggling has a destabilizing effect on border communities, requiring involvement from various sectors. Existing penalties for smugglers are inadequate, and laws often fail to reach all involved parties. Enforcement is challenging due to much of the activity occurring outside the US. Alien smuggling rings operate outside the US, requiring extraterritorial jurisdiction for prosecution. Smuggling can involve dangerous conditions, putting individuals at high risk of harm. The Department of Homeland Security will check alien smugglers and smuggled individuals against terrorist watchlists at U.S. borders. Additionally, there will be stronger prosecution and punishment for alien smugglers. Section 274(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to address the smuggling of unlawful and terrorist aliens. The amendment includes provisions for bringing, recruiting, transporting, and harboring individuals who lack lawful authority to be in the United States. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to address the smuggling of unlawful and terrorist aliens. It includes provisions for harboring, concealing, or transporting individuals who lack lawful authority to be in the United States. Violators face fines, imprisonment, or both for each alien involved. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to address smuggling of unlawful and terrorist aliens, with provisions for harboring, concealing, or transporting individuals lacking lawful authority in the US. Violators face fines, imprisonment, or both based on the offense committed. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to address smuggling of unlawful and terrorist aliens, with provisions for fines and imprisonment based on the offense committed, including serious bodily injury, endangering lives, or involvement in terrorist activity. There is extraterritorial jurisdiction over the offenses described in paragraph (1). Extraterritorial jurisdiction is established for offenses related to smuggling unlawful and terrorist aliens. In cases occurring on the high seas, a necessity defense is limited unless certain conditions are met, including reporting to the Coast Guard and not facilitating illegal entry of aliens into the US. The defense for violating subsection (a)(1)(A) is allowed for religious organizations enabling unpaid ministers or missionaries in the US. The term 'United States' includes various territories. The term 'lawful authority' in the context of immigration laws of the United States excludes authority obtained through fraud or violation of law. It includes permission, authorization, or waiver expressly provided for in the regulations. SEC. 5. MARITIME LAW ENFORCEMENT. Penalties for violating section 2237 of title 18, United States Code include fines or imprisonment up to 5 years. For specific offenses related to alien smuggling, trafficking, or serious bodily injury, penalties can increase to up to 15 years imprisonment. In cases involving death, kidnaping, aggravated sexual abuse, or attempted murder, offenders can face fines, imprisonment up to life, or both. Additionally, the necessity defense is limited in prosecutions under this section. In cases involving death, kidnaping, aggravated sexual abuse, or attempted murder, offenders can face fines, imprisonment up to life, or both. The necessity defense allows for reporting to emergency personnel and the Coast Guard in certain circumstances. The term 'transportation under inhumane conditions' is defined as transporting persons in unsafe ways such as in engine compartments, storage compartments, or at excessive speeds, exceeding the rated capacity of the means of transportation, or intentionally grounding a vessel with persons on board. SEC. 6. AMENDMENT TO THE SENTENCING GUIDELINES. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and potentially amend sentencing guidelines for alien smuggling offenses and obstruction of boarding. Considerations include enhancements for offenses involving flagrant violations, commercial organizations, large groups of transported aliens, endangerment of lives, and facilitation of terrorist activity. The United States Sentencing Commission may amend guidelines for alien smuggling and obstruction of boarding offenses, considering enhancements for endangerment of lives and facilitation of terrorist activity. Expedited procedures may be used for promulgating these guidelines. The Sentencing Act of 1987 allows for the authority to be extended, as passed by the House of Representatives on May 22, 2007.
